column2: Destroying Rome...
Pillaging Monanstaries...
Preserving Latin...
Stamping out the Light...
Spreading Christianity...
Tracing Migration Routes...
Invading the Limes...
Creating the Dark Ages..
Spreading the Plaugue...
Beginning the Chants...
Filling the Library of Alexandria...
Receiving the Byzantine Heralds...
Drawing Maps of Old Rome...
Crossing the Rhine...
Building Huts...
Building Ships...
Conquering the Saxon Shore...
Receiving Mediterranean Merchants...
Summoning the Heralds...
Writing Bibles...
Making the world stop making sense...
Founding Tolosa...
Gathering the High Council...
Crossing the Dividing Sea...
Celebrating the Blot...
Wandering the Steppes...
Spreading the Plauge...
Preparing Islam...
Gathering the High Council...
Destroying Rome...
Oh how the world no longer makes sense!
The Barbarians, and the Dark Ages are here to stay.
Syragius of Soissons is the last Roman ruler in Northern Gaul, and has one last chance to restore Roman glory before the Franks grind his realm into dust.
While the Germanic Arians control great kingdoms the native Chalcedonian Christians are heavily resistant to conversion.
The Hepthalites may look strong but they are just the beginning of the terror from the steppes…...
The Saxon Invasion of Britain has begun, and Arthur is nowhere to be found.
The Emperor in the East, Zeno, is an Isaurian, viewed as distrustful and barbaric by the Greeks.
Deep in the lands of Odoacer, the Roman Senate continues status quo. Will Rome be reborn as a Republic?
Thank Zusk, Ekorovin, Joemit, Erik W, AnaxXiphos for making this possible.
If you don't like your current home, Migrate. The grass is always greener on the other side.
Clovis, the child of the Chieftain of Salia has a good future...
The Bolghar tribes of the Steppes violently fight and migrate, occasionally busting into a bordering nation, raiding and destroying everything.
Chalcendonians must be careful, for relations between the Patriarchs of Constantinople and Rome have been tense.
Insular Christianity still has that flair of the old celtic ways, but the Pope may demand proper communion.
The Sassanids are in a dangerous position, with Mazdakites, Nestorians and Manicheans disrupting the peace.
Keep an eye on Mecca...
The Restorer of the Western Empire can also restore the Legions.
The Bosporans have been practicing some strange religions in Crimea...
The Geatish kings have not played a part in the invasions by the Jutes and Saxons. If their mighty nation though was to choose, Britain could be theirs.
The Nabateans have since been reduced to peasants, and there kingdom has been lost.
Ernakh still lives, and with him, the Huns.
The Ghassanids, and their sudden converion to Monophysitism has left them and the Eastern Empire on rought terms, but will the Emperor risk his most valuable buffer state.
If you find bugs, tell me.
By Germanic steel the Romans fall, but by Roman words are the Germans moved.
If the Western Empire falls the Eastern Emperor can task their loyal foederati the Ostrogoths to invade
The Himyarites have finally won their century long struggle with Saba, but now, they are surrounded with enemies.
Glycerius, a former Emperor is currently a bishop right under Julius Nepos' nose.
This is not the age of Crusades, this is not the age of stable realms, this is the Dark Ages, and nobody is safe from German steel.
Like Pompey, Like Caesar, the greatest enemy of a Roman is another Roman.
Sub-Roman Realms are dotted throughout this made world. Is there hope for he Empire yet?
The Vandals may be powerful, but they are quickly alienating their people with Arian, Germanic ways.
It is madness to resist the Dark Ages, only to survive them.
How would the world have changed if instead of the Franks it was Alamannia?
The Tocharians of the Tarim Basin are small, but could come to dominate the Steppes.
The Celts still live in the Isles, with the druids guiding as in the days of old.
Syagrius might not be able control his Romano-Gallic vassals, who view the Roman Rex as weak.
Centuries of weak rulership and constant raids by the Hepthals have put the mighty Gupta at the brink of destruction.
English culture is an end result of an incredible set of coincidences. Could it ever happen again?
Currently the Britons are united, but in time will come Welsh and Cumbric divisions.
Armorica was the hardest part of the mod.
The King of Lazica has declared Zoroastrianism the state religion, Could he survive?
There are still Celts in Spain!
A brave Briton could stand up to the Saxons, but resistance is fuitile.
If you thought the Senate was hard, try the Praefecti Urbi.
The Eastern Roman Senate is even weaker, but could a Byzantine Republic rise?
Germanic leaders must struggle with the changing times.
Welcome to the Older Gods!
Anything is possible in this world.
The Frisians live in a desolate land, but perhaps there is better to be found in Regia.
The Alans have traveled a great deal, but is Georgia truly their final home?
Laudate Syagrius Rex! Long Live Rome!
The Libyans worship the god Gurzil, the offspring of Amun and a cow.
The Punic Identity has all but been extinguished. Still, some nomads living deep in the sahara claim heritage from that long lost kingdom...
The Libyans worship the god Gurzil, the offspring of Amun and a cow.
The many Hellenic mystery cults that flurished before the rise of Christianity still have bases of operation from Africa to the Levant
A strong ruler with a claim on a unformed empire can use a claim on it as a basis for invasions
The Belemmyes of Eastern Africa worship the god Mandulis, a Nubian corruption of the Egyptian God Horus.
The Slavs of the Steppe have been rapidly increasing their rate of expansion, if unchecked they could destroy the known world just as the Germans did!
While the Suebians may be Arian underneath them the Macromanni are still pagans.
Deep inside the Persian empire sits the Hellenic kingdom of Maysan, the last remnant of the empire of Alexander the Great
If the empire of Rome falls the Roman identity will fall with it.
Traders of the greater Indian Ocean trade have been using Socotra as a base of operations for some time...
While most of Ireland has been converted to Christianity the descendants of Niall of the Nine Hostages, the Ua Nï¿½ill remain staunch pagans.
Most of the Bolghar tribes of the Steppe have a heavy amount of Hunnic influence, in time the Huns may settle into the land and be forgotten.
The tribe of Vascones worship the Roman God Juptier.
Irish monks have settled the northern island known as Iceland.
Deep in the lands of the Persians some still claim heritage from the ancient Assyrians.
While worship of the Egyptian gods has all but been stamped out in Egypt the Garamantes are continuing the Pharaonic legacy with great pyramids and mummification.
In Mauretania, a form of African Latin is spoken by the residents of the Sub-Roman Kingdom.
In the mountains of Caucaisian Albania, the last of the Parthian Arsacrids make their stand.
The city of Yathrib in Arabia is home to a powerful Jewish Merchant Republic, but various pagan families seek to take control of the lucrative nation.
